proud.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: feeling pleased about something that you have done or something that you own, or about someone or something you are involved with or related to
proud.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Seth was the proud owner of a new sports car.
The company is justly proud of its achievements.
Her parents are very proud of her.
You should be proud of yourself.
His past record is certainly something to be proud of.
Seven-year-old Ian is proud to have earned his red belt in karate.
She was proud that the magazine had agreed to publish one of her stories.
proud.translation[0].definitions[0].note: You are proud of someone or something
proud.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: thinking that you are more important, skilful etc than you really are – used to show disapproval
proud.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: a proud man who would not admit his mistakes
proud.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: having respect for yourself, so that you are embarrassed to ask for help when you are in a difficult situation
proud.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Some farmers were too proud to ask for government help.
proud.translation[0].note_box[0].section: Your family must be very proud of you.
He is justifiably proud of what he and his father achieved.
They are fiercely proud of their native land.
He said he was immensely proud to have been elected prime minister.
She was intensely proud of being Japanese.
She is now the proud owner of a four-bedroomed house.
Mark is the proud father of a three-week-old baby boy.
proud.translation[0].note_box[1].section: proud
very pleased with what you, your family, or your country have achieved, or of something you own
I felt so proud when my son graduated from college.
Judith’s very proud of her new Ferrari.
pleased with yourself
feeling pleased because something good has happened, especially because you think you have been very clever, skilful etc
He was smoking a big cigar and was obviously pleased with himself.
I’d made a big profit and was feeling pretty pleased with myself.
arrogant
behaving in an unpleasant and annoying way, because you think you are better or know more than other people, and that your opinions are always right
He was arrogant and regarded people who disagreed with him as fools.
his arrogant attitude to women
vain
too proud of your appearance, in a way that annoys other people
He’s so vain – he thinks all the girls fancy him.
conceited/big-headed
proud of yourself because you think you are very intelligent, skilful, beautiful etc, especially without good reason and in a way that annoys people
Stewart’s the most arrogant conceited person I’ve ever known.
She was offered a brilliant job and became incredibly big-headed overnight.
pompous
thinking that you are much more important than you really are, and using very long and formal words to try to sound important
The clerk was a pompous little man with glasses.
a pompous speech
smug
pleased with yourself in a quiet but annoying way because you think you are in a better position than other people
Milly was looking very smug about coming top of the class.
a smug expression
self-satisfied
pleased with what you have achieved and showing it clearly in an annoying way
She glared angrily into his self-satisfied face.
a self-satisfied grin
